poem_title: THE AULD FARMER'S NEW-YEAR-MORNING SALUTATION TO HIS AULD MARE, MAGGIE, ON GIVING HER THE ACCUSTOMED RIPP OF CORN TO HANSEL IN THE NEW-YEAR.
author: Robert Burns

lines.line_text: A Guid New-year I wish you Maggie!
Hae, there's a ripp to thy auld baggie
Tho' thou's howe-backet, now, an' knaggie,
I've seen the day,
Thou could hae gaen like ony staggie
Out owre the lay.

stanzas.stanza_text:
A Guid New-year I wish you Maggie!
Hae, there's a ripp to thy auld baggie
Tho' thou's howe-backet, now, an' knaggie,
I've seen the day,
Thou could hae gaen like ony staggie
Out owre the lay.

lines.line_text: Tho' now thou's dowie, stiff an' crazy,
An' thy auld hide as white's a daisie,
I've seen thee dappl't, sleek an' glaizie,
A bonie gray:
He should been tight that daur't to raize thee,
Ance in a day.

stanzas.stanza_text:
Tho' now thou's dowie, stiff an' crazy,
An' thy auld hide as white's a daisie,
I've seen thee dappl't, sleek an' glaizie,
A bonie gray:
He should been tight that daur't to raize thee,
Ance in a day.

lines.line_text: Thou ance was i' the foremost rank,
A filly buirdly, steeve an' swank,
An' set weel down a shapely shank,
As e'er tread yird;
An' could hae flown out owre a stank,
Like onie bird.

stanzas.stanza_text:
Thou ance was i' the foremost rank,
A filly buirdly, steeve an' swank,
An' set weel down a shapely shank,
As e'er tread yird;
An' could hae flown out owre a stank,
Like onie bird.

lines.line_text: It's now some nine-an'-twenty-year,
Sin' thou was my Guidfather's Meere;
He gied me thee, o' tocher clear,
An' fifty mark;
Tho' it was sma', 'twas weel-won gear,
An' thou was stark.
When first I gaed to woo my Jenny,
Ye then was trottan wi' your Minnie:
Tho' ye was trickie, slee an' funnie,
Ye ne'er was donsie;
But hamely, tawie, quiet an' cannie,
An' unco sonsie.

stanzas.stanza_text:
When first I gaed to woo my Jenny,
Ye then was trottan wi' your Minnie:
Tho' ye was trickie, slee an' funnie,
Ye ne'er was donsie;
But hamely, tawie, quiet an' cannie,
An' unco sonsie.

lines.line_text: That day, ye pranc'd wi' muckle pride,
When ye bure hame my bonie Bride:
An' sweet an' gracefu' she did ride
Wi' maiden air!
KYLE-STEWART I could bragged wide,
For sic a pair.

stanzas.stanza_text:
That day, ye pranc'd wi' muckle pride,
When ye bure hame my bonie Bride:
An' sweet an' gracefu' she did ride
Wi' maiden air!
KYLE-STEWART I could bragged wide,
For sic a pair.

lines.line_text: Tho' now ye dow but hoyte and hoble,
An' wintle like a saumont-coble,
That day, ye was a jinker noble,
For heels an' win'!
An' ran them till they a' did wauble,
Far, far behin'!

stanzas.stanza_text:
Tho' now ye dow but hoyte and hoble,
An' wintle like a saumont-coble,
That day, ye was a jinker noble,
For heels an' win'!
An' ran them till they a' did wauble,
Far, far behin'!

lines.line_text: When thou an' I were young an' skeigh,
An' Stable-meals at Fairs were driegh,
How thou wad prance, an' snore, an' scriegh,
An' tak the road!
Towns-bodies ran, an' stood abiegh,
An' ca't thee mad,

stanzas.stanza_text:
When thou an' I were young an' skeigh,
An' Stable-meals at Fairs were driegh,
How thou wad prance, an' snore, an' scriegh,
An' tak the road!
Towns-bodies ran, an' stood abiegh,
An' ca't thee mad,

lines.line_text: When thou was corn't, an' I was mellow,
We took the road ay like a Swallow:
At Brooses thou had ne'er a fellow,
For pith an' speed;
But ev'ry tail thou pay't them hollow,
Whare'er thou gaed.

stanzas.stanza_text:
When thou was corn't, an' I was mellow,
We took the road ay like a Swallow:
At Brooses thou had ne'er a fellow,
For pith an' speed;
But ev'ry tail thou pay't them hollow,
Whare'er thou gaed.

lines.line_text: The sma', droot-rumpl't, hunter cattle,
Might aiblins waur't thee for a brattle;
But sax Scotch mile, thou try't their mettle,
An' gart them whaizle:
Nae whip nor spur, but just a wattle
O' saugh or hazle.

stanzas.stanza_text:
The sma', droot-rumpl't, hunter cattle,
Might aiblins waur't thee for a brattle;
But sax Scotch mile, thou try't their mettle,
An' gart them whaizle:
Nae whip nor spur, but just a wattle
O' saugh or hazle.

lines.line_text: Thou was a noble Fittie-lan',
As e'er in tug or tow was drawn!
Aft thee an' I, in aught hours gaun,
On guid March-weather,
Hae turn'd sax rood beside our han',
For days thegither.

stanzas.stanza_text:
Thou was a noble Fittie-lan',
As e'er in tug or tow was drawn!
Aft thee an' I, in aught hours gaun,
On guid March-weather,
Hae turn'd sax rood beside our han',
For days thegither.

lines.line_text: Thou never braing't, an' fetch't, an' flisket,
But thy auld tail thou wad hae whisket,
An' spread abreed thy weel-fill'd brisket,
Wi' pith an pow'r,
Till sprittie knowes wad rair't an' risket,
An slypet owre.

stanzas.stanza_text:
Thou never braing't, an' fetch't, an' flisket,
But thy auld tail thou wad hae whisket,
An' spread abreed thy weel-fill'd brisket,
Wi' pith an pow'r,
Till sprittie knowes wad rair't an' risket,
An slypet owre.

lines.line_text: When frosts lay ling, an' snaws were deep,
An' threaten'd labor back to keep,
I gied thy cog a wee-bit heap
Aboon the timmer;
I ken'd my Maggie wad na sleep
For that, or Simmer.

stanzas.stanza_text:
When frosts lay ling, an' snaws were deep,
An' threaten'd labor back to keep,
I gied thy cog a wee-bit heap
Aboon the timmer;
I ken'd my Maggie wad na sleep
For that, or Simmer.

lines.line_text: In cart or car thou never reestet;
The steyest brae thou wad hae fac't it;
Thou never lap, an' sten't, an' breastet,
Then stood to blaw;
But just thy step a wee thing hastet,
Thou snoov't awa.
My Pleugh is now thy bairn-time a';
Four gallant brutes, as e'er did draw;
Forby sax mae, I've sell't awa,
That thou hast nurst:
They drew me thretteen pund an' twa,
The vera warst.
Monie a fair daurk we twa hae wrought,
An' wi' the weary warl' fought!
An' monie an' anxious day, I thought
We wad be beat!
Yet here to crazy Age we're brought,
Wi' something yet.

stanzas.stanza_text:
Monie a fair daurk we twa hae wrought,
An' wi' the weary warl' fought!
An' monie an' anxious day, I thought
We wad be beat!
Yet here to crazy Age we're brought,
Wi' something yet.

lines.line_text: An' think na, my auld, trusty Servan',
That now perhaps thou's less deservin,
An' thy auld days may end in starvin',
For my last fow,
A heapet Stimpart, I'll reserve ane
Laid by for you.

stanzas.stanza_text:
An' think na, my auld, trusty Servan',
That now perhaps thou's less deservin,
An' thy auld days may end in starvin',
For my last fow,
A heapet Stimpart, I'll reserve ane
Laid by for you.

lines.line_text: We've worn to crazy years thegither;
We'll toyte about wi' ane anither;
Wi' tentie care I'll slit thy tether,
To some hain'd rig,
Whare ye may nobly rax your leather,
Wi' sma' fatigue.
